title: HR 669

content: Personally, I agree with it... exotic animals are a serious hazard to our specific ecosystems in the states. While most owners of these types of animals don't just turn them loose in the backyard, they can get out of their cages and there are always the dim-witted few that try to release them when they don't want them anymore. Take for instance the Asian Snakehead. The fish was originally imported in (illegally I might add) for an asian fish market, but the fish is notorious for escaping and surviving long periods of time (8hours or more) out of water. Some turkey dropped a few in the Potomac and now they're reproducing so fast there is worry that they will wipe out all other species of fish in the River. There is also worry that the fish will spread to other connecting areas off of the Potomac. This is one nasty fish and because of ONE @$$bag who decided to "let them go free", now several species of fish may go extinct. So yeah, I'm all for HR 669. Animals shouldn't be carted all over the world just because we think they're cute.

The fish was originally imported in (illegally I might add) for an asian fish market, but the fish is notorious for escaping and surviving long periods of time (8hours or more) out of water. Some turkey dropped a few in the Potomac and now they're reproducing so fast there is worry that they will wipe out all other species of fish in the River. There is also worry that the fish will spread to other connecting areas off of the Potomac. This is one nasty fish and because of ONE @$$bag who decided to "let them go free", now several species of fish may go extinct. So yeah, I'm all for HR 669. Animals shouldn't be carted all over the world just because we think they're cute.
title: HR 669

content: The problem with non-native species, many are prolific. Eventually they crowd out native species which may die as a result of the take over by non-native plants or animals, birds and fish! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: The problem with non-native species, many are prolific. Eventually they crowd out native species which may die as a result of the take over by non-native plants or animals, birds and fish! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
title: HR 669

content: Exotics are all of the above that you mentioned. Regardless of what state you are in, any animal that is not native to the area can cause huge amounts of damage. I personally don't have any problems with a federal law setting the bar and it should be up to the state game wardens to enforce that. And as for your "what's a problem in Florida isn't a problem in Wisconsin"... that is true for some non-native species, but what about, oh let's just say wild hogs... that adapt and take over ANY environment they are introduced to... Southwest Texas and the Southern United States have a HUGE problem with hogs and they're spreading North at incredible rates. Actual PETS will not be affected by this (dogs, cats, bunnies, guinea pigs etc) Some birds and fish may be affected but I personally do not consider them pets and think it rather cruel to cage a bird. I personally don't see this as giving up rights as it is getting something under control that has run rampant and caused considerable amounts of damage to farmlands, homes, ecosystems, livestock, etc.
reply: Exotics are all of the above that you mentioned. Regardless of what state you are in, any animal that is not native to the area can cause huge amounts of damage. I personally don't have any problems with a federal law setting the bar and it should be up to the state game wardens to enforce that. And as for your "what's a problem in Florida isn't a problem in Wisconsin"... that is true for some non-native species, but what about, oh let's just say wild hogs... that adapt and take over ANY environment they are introduced to... Southwest Texas and the Southern United States have a HUGE problem with hogs and they're spreading North at incredible rates. Actual PETS will not be affected by this (dogs, cats, bunnies, guinea pigs etc) Some birds and fish may be affected but I personally do not consider them pets and think it rather cruel to cage a bird. I personally don't see this as giving up rights as it is getting something under control that has run rampant and caused considerable amounts of damage to farmlands, homes, ecosystems, livestock, etc.

title: HR 669

content: quote: Originally posted by Ready2Rumble: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: We don't need more laws, we need less laws. THANK YOU!!! Um the wild hogs, the ones causing the most problems are domestic. You might want to think a little more before you post. At least do a little research. Here's a novel concept on the hog problem. Shoot to kill and stop with the PETA catch and release crap. Hunt them, shoot them, kill them and I'm sure some homeless shelters would benefit from all that meat. So armywife, just because you don't think something is a pet is a good reason to take away others rights? I agree that state game wardens should enforce state laws. US Fish & Wildlife will enforce this if it passes. Your idea of "exotic" differs from mine. Commonly kept birds, reptiles, herps and mammals are not really considered exotics by many. I should get some cheap parakeets, label them as exotic and sell them on craigslist...I could make a fortune since you consider them exotic. Pretty sad. I served my country to preserve my rights. Your husband serves to preserve my rights. YOU sit back, reap the benefits of your husbands service and arm chair quarterback the supportive taking of my rights. Priceless This is all that I'm going to say about the last portion of your post... you have no idea who I am, what I do or anything about my family. My husband, father, grandfather, brother and countless others in my family NOT ONLY served to protect freedoms but also served to protect this country from people that think they have every right to do anything they want. And DO NOT even BEGIN to imply that I take advantage of my disabled husband. On to the the rest of it... Regarding the hog problem domestic pigs are not the problem, I know because my family lives, works and owns a 100 acre ranch out in East Texas and we have a growing hog problem. The problem is domestic pigs that get loose and go ferral then cross breed with wild hogs making a new, very aggressive strain of wild/ferral hogs. We DO shoot to kill, and even eat what we kill, problem comes in that pigs breed fast, a lot faster than you can kill 'em with just guns... now we COULD poision them... but that'd poision the horses and the cattle too since they run on the same areas. And just to throw it in there, where there are hog problems, there aren't homeless shelters... people actually work for a living in those areas. When it comes to things like this, it is the Federal government's job to lay down a law that applies to entire nation, then, the states can add on to that in regards to their specific areas. You want to keep a bird, go find you a nest that the mother has abandoned and raise the hatchlings for yourself, you want a squirrel, do the same thing. You want an aquarium, go catch you some crawfish, a couple perch and a couple small mouth bass... that's a nice little set up for ya. (species may vary depending on your area). I do not think that it is ANYONE'S RIGHT to "own" an animal that does not belong here. I do not think that it is ANYONE'S RIGHT to hold an animal captive that is meant to be in the wild... call me old fashioned, but if it isn't a dog or a cat or an animal used for sustinance or work, I don't think it should be a pet. And I don't want some jack@$$ thinking he can raise a tiger next to our cattle ranch and the dang thing get loose and kill the cattle and then have to be shot. Some animals ARE NOT MEANT to live in the US. Sugargliders, parakeets, cockatiels, etc are all beautiful animals, and I'm sure they make great "pets" for a lot of people, but each one of those, if introduced into the wild and established a population, could drastically and possibly horribly damage the ecosystem around it. There should be better regulation of what comes in and what goes out.
quote: Originally posted by Ready2Rumble: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: We don't need more laws, we need less laws. THANK YOU!!! Um the wild hogs, the ones causing the most problems are domestic. You might want to think a little more before you post. At least do a little research. Here's a novel concept on the hog problem. content: And what about the lady in Connecticut whose chimp (Travis) ripped the face off her best friend? He was probably a cute little brat when he was little, more fun than... a barrel o' monkeys, heh. But now she's getting sued for millions of dollars. And her friend is permanently maimed. Hardly seems worth it. Shoulda left him in the jungle.

title: HR 669

content: In every state there are endangered and protected animals... I suggest you do more research than to say that NO wildlife is legal to catch and keep (for example, a box turtle is perfectly fine, geckos, salamanders, butterflies, cicadas, etc) In fact, in most states, it is only illegal to hunt, kill, or possess game animals, endangered species, threatened species, state birds/fish/etc, or any other species specifically detailed in their Parks and Wildlife Code. If you'd like to read up on TX state codes... follow this link. Chapter 63 specifies Animals, and there are of course sub-sections from there. <<http://tlo2.tlc.state.tx.us/statutes/pw.toc.htm>> This message has been edited. Last edited by: armywifefigueroa, Wed 15 April 2009 01:57 PM
reply: In every state there are endangered and protected animals... I suggest you do more research than to say that NO wildlife is legal to catch and keep (for example, a box turtle is perfectly fine, geckos, salamanders, butterflies, cicadas, etc) In fact, in most states, it is only illegal to hunt, kill, or possess game animals, endangered species, threatened species, state birds/fish/etc, or any other species specifically detailed in their Parks and Wildlife Code. If you'd like to read up on TX state codes... follow this link. Chapter 63 specifies Animals, and there are of course sub-sections from there. <<http://tlo2.tlc.state.tx.us/statutes/pw.toc.htm>> This message has been edited. When it comes to things like this, it is the Federal government's job to lay down a law that applies to entire nation, then, the states can add on to that in regards to their specific areas. You want to keep a bird, go find you a nest that the mother has abandoned and raise the hatchlings for yourself, you want a squirrel, do the same thing. You want an aquarium, go catch you some crawfish, a couple perch and a couple small mouth bass... that's a nice little set up for ya. (species may vary depending on your area). I do not think that it is ANYONE'S RIGHT to "own" an animal that does not belong here. I do not think that it is ANYONE'S RIGHT to hold an animal captive that is meant to be in the wild... call me old fashioned, but if it isn't a dog or a cat or an animal used for sustinance or work, I don't think it should be a pet. And I don't want some jack@$$ thinking he can raise a tiger next to our cattle ranch and the dang thing get loose and kill the cattle and then have to be shot. Some animals ARE NOT MEANT to live in the US. Sugargliders, parakeets, cockatiels, etc are all beautiful animals, and I'm sure they make great "pets" for a lot of people, but each one of those, if introduced into the wild and established a population, could drastically and possibly horribly damage the ecosystem around it. There should be better regulation of what comes in and what goes out.
quote: Originally posted by Ready2Rumble: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: We don't need more laws, we need less laws. THANK YOU!!! Um the wild hogs, the ones causing the most problems are domestic. You might want to think a little more before you post. At least do a little research. Here's a novel concept on the hog problem. Shoot to kill and stop with the PETA catch and release crap. Hunt them, shoot them, kill them and I'm sure some homeless shelters would benefit from all that meat. So armywife, just because you don't think something is a pet is a good reason to take away others rights? I agree that state game wardens should enforce state laws. US Fish & Wildlife will enforce this if it passes. Your idea of "exotic" differs from mine. Commonly kept birds, reptiles, herps and mammals are not really considered exotics by many. I should get some cheap parakeets, label them as exotic and sell them on craigslist...I could make a fortune since you consider them exotic. Pretty sad. I served my country to preserve my rights. Your husband serves to preserve my rights. YOU sit back, reap the benefits of your husbands service and arm chair quarterback the supportive taking of my rights. Priceless
reply: This is all that I'm going to say about the last portion of your post... you have no idea who I am, what I do or anything about my family. My husband, father, grandfather, brother and countless others in my family NOT ONLY served to protect freedoms but also served to protect this country from people that think they have every right to do anything they want. And DO NOT even BEGIN to imply that I take advantage of my disabled husband. On to the the rest of it... Regarding the hog problem domestic pigs are not the problem, I know because my family lives, works and owns a 100 acre ranch out in East Texas and we have a growing hog problem. The problem is domestic pigs that get loose and go ferral then cross breed with wild hogs making a new, very aggressive strain of wild/ferral hogs. We DO shoot to kill, and even eat what we kill, problem comes in that pigs breed fast, a lot faster than you can kill 'em with just guns... now we COULD poision them... but that'd poision the horses and the cattle too since they run on the same areas. And just to throw it in there, where there are hog problems, there aren't homeless shelters... people actually work for a living in those areas. When it comes to things like this, it is the Federal government's job to lay down a law that applies to entire nation, then, the states can add on to that in regards to their specific areas. You want to keep a bird, go find you a nest that the mother has abandoned and raise the hatchlings for yourself, you want a squirrel, do the same thing. You want an aquarium, go catch you some crawfish, a couple perch and a couple small mouth bass... that's a nice little set up for ya. (species may vary depending on your area). I do not think that it is ANYONE'S RIGHT to "own" an animal that does not belong here. I do not think that it is ANYONE'S RIGHT to hold an animal captive that is meant to be in the wild... call me old fashioned, but if it isn't a dog or a cat or an animal used for sustinance or work, I don't think it should be a pet. And I don't want some jack@$$ thinking he can raise a tiger next to our cattle ranch and the dang thing get loose and kill the cattle and then have to be shot. Some animals ARE NOT MEANT to live in the US. Sugargliders, parakeets, cockatiels, etc are all beautiful animals, and I'm sure they make great "pets" for a lot of people, but each one of those, if introduced into the wild and established a population, could drastically and possibly horribly damage the ecosystem around it. There should be better regulation of what comes in and what goes out.
title: HR 669

content: And what about the lady in Connecticut whose chimp (Travis) ripped the face off her best friend? He was probably a cute little brat when he was little, more fun than... a barrel o' monkeys, heh. But now she's getting sued for millions of dollars. And her friend is permanently maimed. Hardly seems worth it. Shoulda left him in the jungle.

title: HR 669

content: In every state there are endangered and protected animals... I suggest you do more research than to say that NO wildlife is legal to catch and keep (for example, a box turtle is perfectly fine, geckos, salamanders, butterflies, cicadas, etc) In fact, in most states, it is only illegal to hunt, kill, or possess game animals, endangered species, threatened species, state birds/fish/etc, or any other species specifically detailed in their Parks and Wildlife Code. If you'd like to read up on TX state codes... follow this link. Chapter 63 specifies Animals, and there are of course sub-sections from there. <<http://tlo2.tlc.state.tx.us/statutes/pw.toc.htm>> This message has been edited. Last edited by: armywifefigueroa, Wed 15 April 2009 01:57 PM
